description.text:
This Pavillion was part of a housing project designed by Steven Holl in Makuhari, in the sorroundings of Japan, in 1996.
The architect conceived it as an "active structure". This is a dynamic space for the daily activities of the community. It dialogues with the sorrounding space using the water as an element to create the atmosphere.

I'm an architecture student and I did this 3D project for a subject. I modelated this thing using some planes found in the internet.
Microstation was used to recreate the building.

Note: Real photos extracted from Google.

This thing was printed on my Prusa i3 Hephestos by BQ.
It was splitted in two pices in order to keep the inside clean and smooth and allowing to show the interior.
It was sliced in Cura with this settings:
Layer height: 0.2 1st part / 0.1 2nd part
Shell thickness: 1.2
Retraction of 5mm, 150mm/s
Bottom/Top thickness: 1.2
Print speed: 70
Temperature: 220
Support type: Lines. Everywhere with 15% amount.

  5. Slide strain relief over the connector.

author: Marco222

description.text: This is a derivitive box with a lattice work top based on "Islamic Pattern Lasercut Box by hirmes "http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:847". The top pattern is cut out so you can see into the box, the interior pattern on the bottom of the box is only an engraving, without any cutouts.

This is a small box that can be cut out of any material on a laser cutter, preferably  1/8 inch wood or plastic. The wood gets a nice pattern from the laser burns. 
The layout is for a 24x12 piece of material, but there is space leftover for cutting out something else. 
The top of the box will be a lattice with the spaces in the pattern cut out. The bottom panel has the pattern engraved, but without cutouts. 
Use hardwood settings for the laser cutter for both Vector and Raster.
Before you remove the wood from the laser cutter, make sure all the vector cuts are complete, if any pieces arenâ€™t completely cut through, print another pass with the laser printer set to â€œVector onlyâ€ so that it doesnâ€™t engrave the pattern a second time. You can also isolate the pieces that did not print by deleting completed sections of the box from the design. 
Once the laser cuts are complete, assemble the box and glue the seams from the inside using white glue. You can also use a glue gun, but it is not as clean. A photo is included to help with your assembly.

Heater block and M3 stud thermistor from this hotend design were published before as DIY parts. Now, whole hotend is available for 3mm and 1.75mm filaments with 0.5, 0.35 and 0.25mm nozzles. Advantages of this design:
  • Barrel is not fully threaded. 1/4" hex (7mm in metric version) in the middle of the barrel can be held with wrench to screw on-off nozzles without use of two M6 nuts, to establish grip with barrel. You don't need barrel for each nozzle you use, as it is suggested for fully threaded barrels.
  • Easy to install ceramic heater secured with M3 setscrew.
  • Screw-on hex brass body thermistor.
  • Second setscrew M3 x 6 holds Heater block position on the barrel, it prevents block from twist during nozzle change.
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/221232383689
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/221232379661

http://2x2.us/mg-plus-assembly-instructions.pdf
http://2x2.us/mg15-hotend-assembly.pdf
http://2x2.us/mg11-heater-block-assembly.pdf Assembly instructions, Exploded View drawings in PDF format are available for download. 3D STEP and STL models are supplied. Wiki page planned, but not created / published yet. MG Plus Heater Block and screw-on thermistor were published here already, as a separate thing, with drawings and instructions. Other drawings in works and planned to be published.

comments.text: Will this hot end fit the Magergear M2?  Also, can this hot end operate at 240 °C?  Do you sell replacement cartridges?
comments.author: quaverf

comments.text: I did not tried myself, but I had customers buying it to install on M2. I see no problems, technically it should work, although JST thermistor connector on MG Plus is different from one used on Makergear hotend. 240C should not be a problem, MG Plus uses same PEEK and PTFE plastics as Makergear. I hope this helps.
comments.author: quaverf

comments.text: I see no  cooling vents on the insulator. How reliable is PLA printing with this HotEnd?
comments.author: mrbluesky

comments.text: Dimensions of the PEEK/PTFE mount, length of the barrel on MG Plus are different from J-Head, they are like on Makergear hotend. This is done for compatibility purposes and to utilize proven in real life solution known to be reliable with PLA and ABS. J-Head has whole barrel inside PEEK, which is why, I think, it need vents, while MG Plus has larger part of the barrel outside of PEEK mount. I had no complaints about print with PLA till now, so I think MG Plus mount design is fairly all right and need no rework as far as implementing vents.

A bracket/mount for the international edition of Allted's Mostly Printed CNC (thing:790533), to fit a Dremel multi-tool. Specifically designed to fit the Dremel 4000 model, but should fit others with the same shape.

Thought that the Dremel itself might be more capable of cutting than the flexible shaft, so designed this part.

There are two parts to the bracket that fit with Allted's original international edition nut trap.

The lower part, as its name suggests, is attached on the lower end of the Z axis. The upper part, likewise is attached part way up the Z axis.

All holes designed to fit 4mm machine screws. Use one to tighten the lower part and two for the upper (V1) or four if printing V2.

My first version was a really tight fit, so I made the upper bracket two parts instead; should be much easier to fit the Dremel tool, but I haven't tested it. No need to print upper(V1) if you print V2.

Likewise, I have not actually tested these brackets with the machine running and cutting, so I cannot say whether the Dremel will slip out of place.

author: Mrutyunjay

description.text: I made this for a 3d printer cart I'm working on. It allows me to hang my spools up and out of the way of my printer. I will modify this later to make a more universal fit. Right now it will not fit the cheap, 100mm wide rolls. Most thin rolls (hatchbox, justpla studio, esun) fit easily.

3mm walls and 30% infill makes a very strong part. Larger nozzles make stronger parts.

You can print out spoolholder.stl and mount that straight to a wall. Or you can also print out the spoolholderbacking.stl and use that to mount it to a thin wall. What's that? the screws you have are too long? Mine too so I included a 5mm spacer so you can custom fit.

I'm making household objects. Feel free to link me to anything you make, and i will include them in the next update. You will need a 3d-modeling software so that you can change the size of the drawing to fit your printer. Here are 2 free editing programs that you can use to edit the STL's. SketchUp: http://www.sketchup.com/
Blender: http://www.blender.org/ Thanks for checking this out, and as always, Happy Printing =)

description.text: This is a customizable, fully 3d printable cord stopper for your backpack, sleeping bag or other nylon cord equipped stuff.

You can download and customize the SCAD file itself or just use the customizer for standard tweaks of size, strength and number of circle springs (1 or 2) with or without grippy teeth on one or both sides, etc.  
The supplied .stl file is a pretty good size and configuration for general purposes and has grippy teeth on one side only.  
Take a close look at your sliced g-code before printing.  For some reason KISSlicer (my preferred slicer) often wants to break up the circle spring paths in ways that would weaken them considerably.  Slic3r seems to give better results, but not every time.

comments.text: Nice! Had way too many of these break, a replacement will be handy.

The wheels for my rolling 3d printer cart. Mine are made with a pla inner and tpu outer for smoother rolling. It was my first 5 hour print with tpu and I gotta say I really like the stuff with the right settings.

These wheels slide onto a 50mm dowel. They seem to support a lot of weight while still rolling smoothly!

I would recommend printing the tpu piece first. Then print 10-15mm of the inner piece out of pla. make sure it fits then print out the entire model.

I printed the Inner piece at

  • .95 scale
    -5mm walls and 30% infill (this may be overkill)
    -pla
    -brim 5 lines

I printed the outer piece at
-5mm walls and 20% infill
-tpu

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing contains a box to place the Arduino Mega + Ramps board:
Scalar - EletronicBox.stl

It also supports a 80mm PC fan to cool the whole electronics.

Ramps1.4_Applatie.stl is the same box but it can be printed flat.
You can print it as is using Scalar XL 3D printer.

You will find the LCD front cover:
Scalar - ElectronicBox_LCD.stl

Upgrades:

  • V2.5 : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1437311

Updates:

  • 2016.03.23 - Add left side with simple grid
  • 2016.02.13 - Add Ramps_Box_1.4_Base_V2 that is the base of the box you can use if you plan to mount the LCD on the back. The base has been opened in order to reduce the amount of plastic needed to print it.
  • 2016.02.13 - Updated Ramps_Box_1.4_Fan_Front.stl to reduce the thinkness of it.
  • 2016.02.01 - Changes a lots of models in order for the box to be reversible. You can now choose which side is the front and which one is the back!
  • 2015.10.20 - Added Ramps1.4_Applatie.stl

You will need to print Ramps_Box_1.4_Plain_Front.stl in order to invert the original front into the back of the box.
The LCD display can then be mounted on the back of the box. A spcial hole is now available for to pass the LCD wires.

Also we give you a 80mm fan grid to place on top fore safety issues.
80mmFanGrid.stl

And finally a small goodies that is the LCD knob if the one your received with your LCD 2004 doesn't fit properly.

This package is compatible with the Scalar Family 3D Printers (Scalar M and Scalar XL)
The 3D printers kits can be found here:
http://3dmodularsystems.com

Have a great printing experience!

Evolutive 3D Printers

title: e3dv6 MendelMax 2 Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: v10 file is an updated version...have not tested it but it is based off the v8 file so should work fine. v10 file has support built in so no need to add support with your slicer. v10 may or may not have any real benefits over v8. M3 nuts and bolts are what both are set up for.

This mount fits the e3dv6 on to the MM2 and clamps it into place. It is a direct replacement for the factory design. Works with the aluminum piece to create a very ridged mount. Mine fit very snug...you may want to scale up or down a little to get yours to fit best...mine worked well as is with a little coaxing. I will mostly likely continue to refine it a little bit...but should work for you as is with minimal brain damage.
Make it as heavy duty as you can :)

description.text: The name says it all. I printed these out with TPU and am just amazed at the strength, flex and feel of this stuff. Idk how the pieces would fit with pla but with tpu they are snug and easy to detach.

Print with tpu at whatever settings are best for your printer.

.75mm nozzle
.5mm layers
20mm/s
240C
1.2 extrusion multiplier
20%infill

The original had tolerences that were too loose when printed on my Thing-O-Matic, so I started re-writing the frame in OpenSCAD. This fits together perfectly on my printer and works great. It all snaps together nice and tight and turns smoothly - all plastic no screws! I also added a hand crank to make it easier to turn. This makes an awesome demo object! Here's a video of it in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g73Gw_hJUnE
Print 3 x gears.stl, 1 x gear4.stl, 2 x braces.stl and one of each of the other parts

remixed_from.title: Itty Bitty Double Extruder (with mount for MakerFarm Prusa i3v)

title: Underslung X Endstop for extreme X travel (MakerFarm i3v)

description.text:
This is a new X endstop mount for MakerFarm i3v printers to extend X travel further to the right. This allows the left extruder nozzle on dual extruder setups to reach more of the bed.

On the 12" i3v with the Itty Bitty Double Flex extruder, the left nozzle should be able to reach the edge of the glass, so you can use the entire bed for single-material prints.

The mount installs under the lower X extrusion with an M5 screw and T-nut and provides an opening to route the wires behind the Z screw.

• Install the endstop mount under the X extrusion with an M5 screw and T-nut.
  • Mount the switch with two M2.5x12 screws.
  • Route the switch wires through the opening to keep them in place behind the Z screw.

comments.text: Is there an ETA on the switch?  I'm just about to swap over to the Itty Bitty Flex and it would be great to add this in at the same time.  :-)
comments.author: Mr_Phelps

comments.text: I just discovered there is an interference issue when using this switch location with the Itty Bitty Double Flex extruder because of the shape of the wider shelf supports.  I'll be figuring out how to deal with this and posting some changes.  Stay tuned!

description.text:
I used the original designs below as a base and modified them for the front of a MB replicator 2. They were printed in ColorFabb XT CF20 Carbon Fiber Filament.Use a 5/16" x 6" bolt and a lock nut.

This will fit all ColorFabb spools as well as the Makerbot Spools and many others with the same diameter opening.
I made the guide longer than normal so where the filament feeds in, it would be in the center of the roll.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:394086
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:394086

Print these is ColorFabb XT CF20 for the strength.

Long front spool holder- 40% infill- 2 shells- .20 mm layer height
50 mm long spool holder- 25% infill- 2 shells- .20 mm layer height
Bolt holder- 100 % infill- 2 shells- .20 mm layer height

5LB filmant guide- printed this in Polymaker Polymaxx
20% infill-.2 shells-.20 mm layer height

After printing the long spool holder and bolt holder- ream them out with a 21/64th drill bit -
After assembly tighten the lock nut so there is a little tension so the spool does not turn free ( you want a little drag on it)

description.text: Sits on z-axis rod and guides filament so it doesn't flop around near the print area.

After printing, i had to enlarge the hole that the goes into a little bit using a drill bit. This might have been caused by a z-axis problem I encountered at the start of the print where the axis would not raise enough after each layer. The print started to squish. I put some lubrication on the z-axis rod and manually adjusted the z-axis, and it printed straight for the top half. Didn't reprint the object. Make a comment if the hole needs to be expanded. In the model, it should be 9mm in diameter. In reality, the diameter should be about 8.3mm, so 9mm allows for some shrinkage.

remixed_from.title: Itty Bitty Double Extruder (with mount for MakerFarm Prusa i3v)

title: Adjustable-Tilt X Carriage for Double Extruders on MakerFarm Prusa i3v

description.text:
This is a drop-in replacement for the stock MakerFarm Prusa i3v X carriage mount that adds an additional eccentric on one of the upper wheels. This allows the entire carriage plate to be tilted left and right to level dual extruder nozzles.

This plate will work with both the Itty Bitty Double Extruder and the Itty Bitty Double Flex extruder.

This removes the need to tilt the entire X carriage to level the nozzles.
You will need an additional eccentric cam to install in the larger top wheel hole. Your printer kit may have come with an extra, or you can purchase one from MakerFarm or OpenBuilds.

title: Pump Hand Drill gift set for Grampa

description.text:
this is a remix of Speedy777 Pump Hand Drill (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:731086).
it adds a box to hold the 3 different sizes drills, and the relative bits (diameter of 1.6, 2.4, 3.2 mm).

it fits on a 10x10 bed

we are also including the original drill body files from speedy777 and three separate files for the back nub, the slider and the chuck.

in our experience, printing all the parts at 100% resulted in the slider to be way too tight and not move freely, the back-nub being too big and not clicking in and the chuck screw also to be a little on the small side.
this is likely due to our printer low accuracy.

in any case, we found that printing the body of the drill at 100%, the slider at 109%, the backclip at 95% and the chuck screw at 110% everything works great after some minimal sanding/filing

we printed the shaft upright, at 100% infill with .3mm layers and 3 walls, with a 5mm brim for stability and we slowed down the print to 75% 2/3 up. it takes longer but it limits swaying and thus adds accuracy
we printed the slider at .25 mm layer to avoid the layers to align, and thus ideally reduce friction.

title: El Marino Pendant
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a simple variant of the El Marino Elementary School logo.  It is a fast print intended to show the kids how a 3d printer works, while producing something they can take home.  It can be attached to backpack zippers, worn on a necklace, and more.

For a school demo, I recommend PLA because it can be immediately removed from the print bed upon completion, and it smells more pleasant than ABS.  I use a relatively high .4mm layer height to increase print speed.  It is meant to be printed when reduced to 25% in the X & Y, but with the Z left alone.  At .4mm, this gives a 6 layer print and the pendant is about 1" in diameter.   
I also found the best balance between getting the prints to stick and ease of removal when heating the print bed to 45 degrees C.  I also print a bunch ahead of time, otherwise it will take a while to make enough for the whole class (at my settings I can print one every 1.5 minutes).

author: K987

description.text:
A busy few hours after my first attempt at a useful OpenSCAD design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9446) and I've totally re-written and refactored the code into a parametric part library. It's still early days, but it already contains the basic building blocks and a bunch of basic parts (segments, nozzles, base plate). There is also a demo section in the library that will generate a full set of example parts. Or you can un-comment the lines at the bottom to render individual parts and export the STL. Module Structure
Basic building blocks are defined as chainable modules, taking at least one common parameter - the bore of the hose. Thus alternate hose sizes are trivial to generate (1/4 inch, 1/2 inch, etc). Global Variables
  • tolerance = controls the distance between the ball and socket surfaces
  • definition = this defines the number of facets for curved surfaces (sets the $fn parameter)
    • Parts in the Library
  • Hose segment
  • Extended hose segment (user defined length of "waist" between ball and socket)
  • Round Nozzle (user defined nozzle diameter)
  • Base Plate (user defined screw dia, defaults to M3)
    • Feedback
    Any and all comments welcome, it would be great if someone could print off a few segments and let me know if they work! Updates
    22 Jun 2011 - Uploaded v0.2 library, includes reduced wall thickness and increased distance between ball/socket surfaces (based on feedback from bohnded). Also added DoubleSocket module. For comparison, I've added a cross-sectional view of the latest hose segment alongside the loc-line part by charlespax - the ball/socket offset on my model is obviously still a bit tighter than charles', but not sure whether I should increase it further...?
I've not yet built my 3D printer, so I can't test the part. If anyone is up for being a guinea pig, I'll happily modify the design based on your feedback.

author: MuuSer

description.text:
Bought a Hexagon Hotend upgrade for my Taz 4 from Maker Farm and needed a way to cool it with a 40mm fan. Tried the shroud from this thing but my PLA prints kept failing after a short time due to filament expansion. The design was good but the Maker Farm hexagon model differs slightly from the Lulzbot version in that the heater block is smaller and the heat sink region is longer.

I took the same basic design but lengthened the adapter part to cool the bottom heat sink fins on the hotend. Since heat creep starts at the fins close to the heater block, we have to keep them cool to prevent jams.

I tried working in Autodesk 123D Design for this project. The model is by no means perfect but it's functional and I haven't had PLA jams so far.

(**Update. Added 123dx working file with the pieces i used to make the shroud in various states for anyone else to maybe remix or fix this design.)

Although the model looks fine, I couldn't get it to slice properly in Cura or Simplify3D. Sliced perfectly fine in Slic3r at 0.2mm layer height with 2 shells. Use supports for the hanging tab and be sure to print in ABS so the shroud doesn't melt on the hotend.

See the attached picture and the one at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:845113 for mounting. The fan shroud actually clips on pretty good on the hotend by itself. But it's best to secure with the tab and the stock hardware securing the extruder assembly to the Taz extruder mount.

Note
If you're upgrading a Taz4 to a 3rd party Hexagon hotend (Makerfarm etc..), make sure that you print the updated extruder mount, body, and idler parts to match with the new hardware. The hexagon will not fit the standard Budaschnozzle printed extruder assembly. Please see general upgrade notes below:

Make sure to get a 24V heater to match the Taz power system if you don't want to modify the firmware.

Extruder Mount:
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/5.0/production_parts/printed_parts/extruder_mount_hex/extruder_mount_hex.STL

Hex Extruder Body: http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/5.0/production_parts/printed_parts/extruder_body_3mmhex_Mini/extruder_body_3mmhex_v1.0.stl

Hex Extruder Idler: http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/5.0/production_parts/printed_parts/extruder_idler/extruder_idler_v1.4.stl

You can use the Taz 5 firmware directly: http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/5.0/software/2015Q1/firmware/Marlin_2015Q1_TAZ5.tar.gz

General Hexagon upgrade wiring: (you'll need to get some of your own parts or hack the connections together)
https://ohai-kit.alephobjects.com/project/taz4-hexagon-toolhead/

Instead of connecting a 5V fan I recommend getting a 24v 40mm fan and connecting it to the 2nd extruder fan connection on the RAMBO board. You'll want as much airflow as possible on the hexagon hotend to avoid any filament jams with PLA. You can control the 2nd extuder fan with GCode commands without modifying the firmware.

M106 P0 S255 <- Turns on the FIRST fan M106 P1 S255 <- Turns on the SECOND fan

title: Overlord Pro - coroplast arc door frame

description.text:
Two arcs that create a removable door made mostly of 4mm coroplast. 5x3x20mm neodymium magnets are pushed down the flutes to help affix the door to the frame. The bottom arc has a hook that is profiled to the plastic base of the Overlord Pro and I'm assuming Overlord as well.

Parts work as is, but improvements are being made over time.
Use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:945704 to hold the door to the printer. Use the flute spacer to help get the right distance between magnets inside the flutes of the doors.

Fan mount comes in two parts and hold an open frame 120mm fan with the use of four 3mmx25mm screws and nuts.

Note: I added two fans to one of my doors. The lower fan when using both inner and outer frames, does just barely touch one of the ball joints of the effector on the left side of the printer. So, If you're going to put in a low mounted intake fan, think about your placement and do not use the inner fan mount. Use fender washers instead.

Inspirated by indian architecture
I decided to do a sand mold for my infinite stairs castle (see entry #929228). So this is the first try on a pyramid mold and a mold for one pair of mirrored stairs to decorate the pyramid. Both molds should be scalable and always in relation to another, so that the stairs fit exactly on the big pyramid.

  • I made it customizable, see instructions for further information.

In contrary to my first entry of the fancy and huge infinite stairs castle, this would really be printable.

Follow up:

  • My goal is that the molds are scalable together, in relation to another.
  • I am trying to figure out how to do a mold for my linear extrusion tower, which sits on top of the infinite stairs castle. But this won't be easy, as the tower will sit in the mold like a screw inside a thread.

For customizing:

  • The "scale" factor determines how big the mold will be. The number of steps on the stairs also changes with scale, to make sure that the steps will be printable and also shapeable in sand.

  • Scale ranges from 50 to 250, in Steps of 10. It is meant to be %, so scale=100 is the original size.

  • The standard mold should fit into an bigger 3d printer. It is ca. 87mm in height, which is not a problem, but relatively wide.

  • If it doesn't fit on the buildplate, just scale it down a little bit.

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder and Handle (UPDATED)

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder and Handle Rods

description.text: The Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:322923 required the use of PVC piping to build. Being that I didn't want to head out to a store and do any cutting. I decided to print the rods up. This allows for really nice custom colors for the filament holder. Although I wanted straight black for mine.

You will need 4 spool holder rods and one Axel rod.

For the Axel rod, use 20% infill, .3mm layer height, .8mm shell thickness (2 walls) and made sure to print end caps.

For the spool holder rods, there's no need for any infill or end caps, but you could. I personally wanted them to print a bit quicker. They are quite sturdy and thick without the infill. Use a brim for better adhesion.

author: killer50

description.text:
This part replaces the acrylic part for the Y idler. The front Y rod goes through the gap in the foot part and the adjuster block pushes onto the end of the rod. This allows the height of the rod to be fine tuned to remove any twist and allow you to get the bed level at the front. You will also need an M3 bolt I have used a cap head as can be seen in the picture and an M3 nyloc nut, this passes through the hole in the top of the idler bracket through the adjuster block and secured it with the nut underneath. You can then move the rod up and down by tightening or loosening the bolt.

May also be compatible with Ormerod 1

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
It's summer and the sun is very hot. Buy a fan is boring.
So why don't print a selfmade fan with 5 speed steps? - from silent to cool down! ;-)

What can you do next? Take this fan to a place where is a lot of wind or use wind enery from a exhaust of a machine and use it the other way round to produce energy!

https://youtu.be/SXH6br8nqws

Have Fun!

You need a Motor, a switch and some screws.
I don't know the motor and switch type, so i made a plan with the most important meassures. You can find the plan in the pictures.
You also need three DIN912 M4x10 screws and two DIN912 M8x25 screws.
The three M4 screws are for the cover on the backside. (you must make three threads in the stand.)
The two M8 screws fix the stand turnable on the foot. (you also must make two threads in the foot, on the inner holes.

A possible variant of a electrical circuit layout is in the pictures too. I this circuit to regulate the speed of the fan.
Operating voltage up to 12V.

you can install the cables in the prepared holes and tunnels. So you don't see them after assembling the components.

author: Michaelmi782

title: Kitchen Aid FGA Meat Grinder Spacer

description.text:
Kitchen Aid's FGA meat grinder has a well-known issue where it creates a "gray goo" as it grinds meat. This "goo" is the result of the 4-blade cutter being too thin for the square shaft it sits on. Therefore the square shaft slowly grinds on the metal cutting disk and creates metal residue that is the "gray goo". Based on reading hundreds of comments and some research on my own, I made this small spacer that goes behind the 4 blade cutter and "raises" it on the square shaft so the grinding is minimized. This also gets the blades flush with the cutter disk so it works better. Main thing, DO NOT OVERTIGHTEN THE SCREW DOWN ring that holds the cutting disk in place! Use gentle hand-tightening and make sure you can turn the main shaft with your fingers before attaching it to the mixer.

Also since bacteria will grow in this part, print several and use a fresh one for each time you grind meat. It prints out in less than 2 minutes, so make a bunch!

title: ZMR250 spacer set with camera holder

description.text: For a lowrider ZMR250 with a PZ0420m camera

Preparation

Shopping list

  • 20 m3 lock nuts
  • 16 m3 25mm aluminium/steel bolts
  • 4 m3 35mm aluminium/steel bolts
  • 2 m3 20mm spacers (for the back end)
  • ZMR250 frame
  • PZ0420m Sony board cam

Print all the parts!

  • 2 side spacers
  • 4 naze spacers
  • 4 arm spacer sets
  • Top camera holder
  • Bottom camera holder

Assembly

Arms

The arms are attached to the top plate with one short bolt (one from the ZMR kit will do) and 3 long bolts (25mm m3). Use the short bolt in the hole closest to the center of the quad to have as much space as possible to put electronics in. Arm spacer placement is quite obvious.

Side spacers

Side spacers go onto the sides, again with 25mm m3 bolts.

Naze32

Naze is attached to the top plate with plastic/nylon m3 bolts and the spacers. The spacers in this thing are made to get the naze as close as possible to the top plate while still keeping (just) enough clearance to be able to plug a cable into the USB socket. 4mm standoffs would accomplish the exact same thing.

Camera

To use the camera holder you will need to make a cut into the top plate to make space for the camera. You can use my cutout as a rough guide or you could look at the top holder and do a lot better. Make sure the short screw on the front arms is secured before installing the holder as these will be covered up by the holder. Check if the camera fits before installing. I had one exact fit print and one that needed a bit of sanding to fit the sides of the cam board. Install the top half first, using 4 3,5cm screws (replacing two arm screws). Slide in the camera and take out the front screws. Now slide the bottom part in and replace the front screws.

Finally

Wire everything up. Pop on the bottom plate and put on all the lock nuts.

author: notabenegroup

description.text: KNOB FOR TAP

These clips are for use on a Micro3D printer (http://www.printm3d.com/#_l_ju) when using external filament. The Sketchup and STL files are scaled x10 so be sure to reduce it by 0.1.

Updated 29 Jul 2015. The clips didn't hold quite as tightly as I would like so I changed the gap a bit. These go on harder but hold pretty well.

Updated 29 Aug 2015. I have redesigned these using OpenSCAD and included the source so you can customize them to suit yourself.

These are easy to "clip" onto the control cable that goes into the print head. They stay pretty well but I have found that because the cable is not solid they do tend to come off over time. What I did was to drill a small hole through the narrow part and use small cable ties to secure them to the control cable.

Use the second version (FilamentClip2) of the STL file which has a slot for securing the clips with small (10 cm) cable ties. Or use the .scad file with OpenSCAD and customize them as you wish.

author: Drakal

print_settings.Notes:: Temp was 210°/60° for Innofil black PLA, 240°/90° for Innofil silver ABS.

description.text:
This is a print head for the Ultimaker 2.
I created it after my second original print head got cracks.

It is a drop in replacement, you can use stock bearings.

The cables are fixed on the outside and the outer part is desinged to be removed by only loosen the four screws.

Desing is mostly influenced by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:703974 but I wanted a drop in replacement not changing the original size and shape too much and not to have to alter the firmware.

UPDATE V1.1:
I created a little improved version.
I change the hole where the bowden tube fix will be inserted, before it was a bit hard to fix the clamp.
Also I thickened the section on the outer body where the cables will be fixed because on my ABS one broke out right away.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

40%/50%

Notes:

Printed with 40% rectilinear infill for PLA and 50% full honeycomb for ABS.

25mm/s overall speed, fist layer 80%, outline 50%, solid infill 80%, support 80%.

Retraction 4.5mm, speed 25mm/s, 0.2mm vertical lift, coasting 1.5mm.

Temp was 210°/60° for Innofil black PLA, 240°/90° for Innofil silver ABS.

Printed with Innofil black PLA and Innofil silver ABS, sliced with Simplify3D v3 with supports.

Printed a second version in ABS because when printing longer time with high temperature the bottom of the parts in contact with the "cold" end deform a little bit. Cold end reaches a temperature a little above glass transtition temp of PLA.
This stops after a while but after the first prints you have to adjust the buildplate every time and retighten the screws.
So I thought ABS is WTG...

author: jorgetfn

title: How to make a very sticky glass printing bed without any additive

description.text:
The problem I tried to solve was that my new perfectly flat printing bed in borosilicate glass was not sticky at all for PLA.

I didn't want to use the sticker papers anymore because the rendering of the surface of the objects in direct contact with the glass is so perfect !!!

I then had the idea to cross sand one of the faces of this glass sheet with 600 sand paper. If the thin scratches are almost invisible (and not visible at all on printed objects), it immediately appeared that they produced a huge effect and gave a strong adherence to the PLA filament on the glass surface.

I exclusively used this sanded glass sheet since, and it worked 100% great every time, always remaining very sticky for PLA provided the glass sheet stays at least at 50°C (I use 228°C for the PLA filament, and 60°C for the printing bed).

Heating at 60/70°C, a huge adherence appears without the need for any glue or whatever else. Just the bare sanded glass sheet. And, magically once the printing bed becomes cold, every printed object, whatever is the size of its surface, just spontaneously separates from the glass surface. No efforts, no tools needed, just remove it as simply as you would take an object placed on a shelf.

I do not know if it is important or no, but just in case, I kept avoiding to touch the surface with my fingers in order to prevent the presence of any oil which would reduce the adherence of the scratched glass. Anyway, there is no need to touch it because as previously said, the objets spontaneously separate from the printing bed once the glass surface becomes cold.

A very interesting and positive side effect of this spontaneous separation is that there is no need to readjust the level of the printing bed once it is even, because there are no efforts to apply on it to unglue the printed objects, so no possible disalignments at this step.

I simply wanted to widely share this successful try, because I know that many are in deep trouble with this adherence issue.

To date, I did not try with any other kinds of filament with this printing bed. I'll update later. However if you can give an update based on your own attemps with this solution or an approaching one which may be helpful for others, you are warmly welcome to add it in the comments.

The uploaded file comes from another of my Things, and is useless. It is here just to allow the publication of the present information.

I hope this tip will be as helpful (life saver ?) for you than it have been for me.

Have a good day !

comments.text: So I did this with 400 grit sandpaper and it worked awesome. Everything stuck amazingly well and came off easily when cooled. I even took a bit of glass of a couple sides because I was impatient - which shows how well it sticks.
comments.author: jawadams

comments.text:
I met almost the same problem after some time. As the problem appeared either during a period where I was printing intensively, and another time while I was not using my printer at all, I deducted that the problem could maybe come from the pollution of the air. I then tried to clean the glass bed with aceton, and in both cases, it immediately and perfectly fixed the problem.
One more thing... From my experience, in no case the sanded glass bed should be touched with the fingers, because it easily attracts and retains the fat of the skin.
comments.author: jawadams

comments.text: I will have to try the acetone. I was always cleaning with alcohol before and have tried glass  cleaner. I'll give it a good scrubbing with a brush and some glass cleaner then try acetone.
comments.author: jlcdi

comments.text: Tried this with a 600 grit as specified and it's been working pretty well. Prints tend to be sticky enough when hot and they pop right off when cold. Would sanding it down with a coarser grit help a bit more? I'm curious if 400 grit or 200 grit would make it that much better at sticking.
comments.author: AdoboPR

comments.text:
Hi AdoboPR,
Thank you for sharing your experience.
I've sanded mine with a 250 grit. I was thinking that some deep scratches would have been better for a good adherence. The result is constantly perfect.
Due to your comment, I now know that 600 grit works fine too. I will try that on next time, because if we are perfectionist, we have to admit that we can slightly (but really very very slightly) see the 250 grit scratches on the printed face which is in contact with the glass.
comments.author: AdoboPR

comments.text: The summary on the front page mentioned 600 so I tried that. I would actually like to go with a coarser grit to see if it helps make it stickier. Additionally it might make the sanding process easier too, which is  a PITA right now.
comments.author: jlcdi

comments.text: Bought 400 grit and 220. Will try 400 first and see if it gives me the results I'm expecting.
comments.author: AdoboPR

comments.text: I sanded my glass pane with 200 grit sandpaper (much rougher than suggested by OP here) and treated the surface with abs juice.
comments.author: Mike13815

comments.text: I have used sanded glass to my Renkforce RF1000 in about 2 months. Works perfect with PLA! Always clean the bed with some kind of spirit before printing. Printing with ABS you have to increase the bed temp to at least 110 degrees Celsius. I use a thin layer of glue-stick for best results. ABS tends to warp with large object.
comments.author: Ludwig100

comments.text:
Hi Ludwig100,
Thank you for your highly valuable feedback for the PLA, and your advices for the ABS. I never yet tried to print with ABS, but I have read comments from users on forums saying that too long straight lines should be avoided on the design of the object at the level of the printing bed in order to avoid the warping effect. Have your heard about that ? Can you give some more detailed feedback about your ABS experiences ? In advance thank you.
comments.author: Ludwig100

comments.text: I do the exact same with kapton tape (cross sand with 500 sandpaper), thanks for the tip, will try it out
comments.author: ormerod168

comments.text:
Hi Ormerod168, Thank you for this useful information. I will try it too for my PLA prints. How do the things happen with the sanded Kapton at the end of the printings ? Is it easy to remove the printed parts from the sanded Kapton tape ?
By the way, did you made some experience with ABS prints on the Kapton tape ?
comments.author: ormerod168

comments.text:
I've printed some large ABS part's on unsanded kapton tape heated to 100°C with a little bit of hairspray (isn't necessary but help's).
The parts come of very easily once the bed cooled down and the surface finish is great!
comments.author: jlcdi

comments.text: I think you underheat your bed. I use about 70C for the 1st layer. The trick is if you print calibration cube it must be soft to touch with a finger. So you need to low down the bed temp for second layer
comments.author: Karabas

comments.text:
Hi Karabas,
Thank you for this useful and very important information.
Previously, I was using the kapton tape (the beige paper one). It was working perfectly except for the aspect of the surface of the printed part which was in contact with the tape.
I then received 3 pieces of glass and 1 roll of large glossy kapton tape. I immediately covered one of the glass sheets with this new kapton, and there was no adherence at all. I searched the forums and saw that the kapton tape is mostly used for ABS. So, for my PLA prints I left this covered glass sheet beside.
When I then installed another of the bare glass beds, I couldn't reach any temperature for which the PLA filament would adhere onto the glass surface. I tried to increase the temperature 5 °C by 5°C, from 40 to 90°C to be sure I will not miss something. The situation was almost the same at any of those temperatures, the bed was far too slippy for anything to be built on it.
At one moment, I washed the glass, thinking that maybe there would be the presence of some invisible fat film or whatever else from the factory. It just went worse.
I then had this idea to cross sand one of the sides of the glass sheet, did it, and immediately everything became perfect.
comments.author: Karabas

comments.text: Thank you for sharing this!  So you sanded in two directions, 90 degrees opposite of each other?  Have you noticed that your heat bed heats less often now?

author: gryphius

description.text:
Make your own homemade car scent clip. The inspiration behind doing this was to make more scents than are currently available for a device I will be putting on Kickstarter next month.

WARNING Scented oils can be very damaging to property! Be very careful what you get it on. Do not use ABS or PLA for printing this. Print with 100% infill. Use at own risk. I have not tested this for very long. Don't know what heat or cold in your car may do at this point. Might be fine might leak and damage car. Will know more as time progresses

Source of Oil: https://www.etsy.com/shop/SaharasSupplies?section_id=5376041&ref=shopsection_leftnav_7

Note: I think the gunpowder smell seems more like Incense... That is why I put the label that says Ninja Oil. I am thinking will use it with a game where you are a ninja! :D

Update 8/5/15

Trying a few more smell oils here are the results
Motor Oil - Seems Accurate
Colombian Coffee- Smells like a can of cold liquid coffee like the kind with milk and sugar :D
Campfire- Smells like some kind of wood. Can't place the kind
Dirt- Smells like Mulch
Sea Salt- Smells like a dirty beach maybe. Another person says it smells like popcorn.

that is it for now will post more updates as I try more scented oils :)

To successfully make one of these you will need the following.

Scented Oil of your choice
Gorilla Glue
Outdoor Fabric
The two 3D printed pieces in PET/T-Glase 100% infill

Assembly

  1. Pour Oil into the first printed part
  2. Cut fabric to fit the square border on the back
  3. Dip fabric in water to activate gorilla glue(most will fall off because it is kind of water proof but it seems to still work)
  4. Apply glue to the square border on the back of the piece
  5. Clamp the all weather fabric(waterproof side down) to the back for two hours with a heavy object
  6. attach second printed part.
  7. Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

title: Fixed Fishbone Gears (47/9 double helix). Wade-Greg-Jonas Kuehling extruder

description.text:
Gears defined initially by Stoffel15 generate a small interference because the large and the small gear not have the same helix angle.
In the previous version the helix for large gear rotates 200Âº/47 and grows upward 5.5mm. Meanwhile the helix of small gear rotates 200Âº/9 and grows upward 6.25mm. In this version helix are matched in both gears, keeping the same definition for the large gear and only changing the rotation of the helix for the small gear to (200Âº/9) * (6.25/5.5) The files are the modified SCAD and two part files modeling in Autodesk Inventor modeling with xls parameters file needed for configuration. In the design of the gears in Inventor has introduced a small clearance in the hollow of the tooth (tooth 19/40 recess 21/40) while the backlash in SCAD = 0 (I left it as it was originally) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=envbj-yDYhI

Need to let out some air from a tire, basketball, soccer ball, football...?
The nose engages the pin in a standard Schrader valve used on many tires, while screwing in a standard needle inflator for the tail will let the air out of balls. (Not sanctioned for NFL use. :-)

Print with the tail surface flat on the build platform, nose in the air.
0.1 mm layers are good to make threads for the needle insert.

author: chrismiester

description.text:
In honor of the release of the latest Daft Punk album, I wanted to print a set of helmets. I couldn't find a decent mesh on thingiverse (I AM DISAPPOINT), so I put this together.
This is a ready to print model of Thomas Bangalter's Daft Punk Helmet. I don't think the two Robots have names, so I've been calling it the visor mask. I gave these out as party gifts, who doesn't like a little daft punk?
The model is just dying for remixes. Keychains, magnets, gear shift knobs, lets do this people! Check out the readme for descriptions of each file.

I would first like to say thanks to Aaron for his excellent model as a starting point:
http://grabcad.com/library/thomas-bangalter-s-daft-punk-helmet I started with Aaron's STEP file, added an interior shell, pushed it through netfabb cloud to get it print ready, and flattened the backside of the helmet. There is also a version with modeled support for the ears. The photos include pictures of this model, as well as one I printed level with full support. I had to use needle nose pliers to remove the modeled support, but I thought the end result looked better than printing level w/ full support. The STL's are reasonably highres, but I've only printed this about the size of a golf ball. As soon as I can find the time, I'll print a larger version. If you want to print this full size and wear it around, you will need to remodel the interior. Let me know if these give you trouble, or would like any other file formats. For the matching set, print Guy's helmet as well:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:95504 Happy printing!

Official page: http://www.tiltdrone.com

=======================================

19th October 2015 (Rev.4):

  • new servo base and servo bearing housing for Emax ES09XX servos (alignment fixed)
  • arms supports to use with 25 mm long stand-offs added
  • arms supports to use with 20 mm long stand-offs (rev.3) re-named
  • tweaked gear supports (right and left versions)
  • Tougher motor mounts design
  • Overall assembly rev.4

20th September 2015 (Rev.3):

  • battery and PDB susbtitution plates STL for TILT 3DP added
  • new versions of: base plate, top plate, servo base, antenna support, arms and servo pulleys, arms support RIGHT&LEFT, gear support RIGHT&LEFT added
  • TILT 3DP assembly model with new parts and mods added
  • list of non-3DP parts needed to complete the kit here: https://tilt-drone.myshopify.com/products/tilt-pro-frame-non-3dp-kit
  • TILT spares and merchandising here: https://tilt-drone.myshopify.com/collections/all

3rd August 2015 (Rev.2):

I just revised all parts and corrected/improved a few. If you already printed the models previous to this rev.2 'thing', you need to re-print:

  • Gear support L and R
  • Antenna support
  • Servo support for Emax ES09XX
  • Gap filler (new part)
  • Front tip action cam (new part)
  • Servo and arm pulleys (optional: we can't guarantee it prints well since the design is for CNC but some asked for it so, here it is!)

I also added the following models to help you figure out where things go:

  • TILT 3DP NO action cam
  • TILT 3DP for action cam

Nevertheless, all parts have been fixed or improved in some way so the best is you print all the parts again.

=======================================

Get your hands on these files and 3D print the whole frame of a dynamic tilting arms miniquad racer! https://www.tiltdrone.com

To make it fly you will still need non-3D printed parts like tilt servo, arms (can be 3D printed!), pulley (can be 3D printed!), etc. If you want to get those parts visit or for those not familiar with the rest of parts selection (motors, ESCs, etc...) https://tilt-drone.myshopify.com/collections/all

Looking forward here to see what you guys do with our files... post in our Facebook pages (see below), here or email us please!

We do run the open source firmware Cleanflight on the Naze32 flight controller (https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/tiltflight-configurator/omcpjdnlgjocjccljjfgoehnnnimpjeo?hl=en) or you program your own flight controller to run the tilt servo ;)

Oh, and plenty of manuals can be found in https://www.facebook.com/groups/DynamicTiltingArmsUsers/files/

Official Facebook page of TILT: https://www.facebook.com/pages/TILT-drone-racer/377017535825189

We use carbon fiber blend filament in most parts (especially structural ones) and PLA in the rest. Of course you can print in any material you wish and we'll be glad if you let us know what have you used and how it works. Send us your pictures and comments at [email protected]

More info at https://www.tiltdrone.com

Note the CC license is 'Attribution - Non-commercial'. If you want to use these files, modifications, derivatives or remixes for commercial use, please contact us.
